choices.B: Constructor injection only allows one value to be injected.
choices.C: Constructor injection is preferred over field injection to support unit testing.
choices.D: Construction injection can be used with multiple constructors without @Autowired annotation.
choices.E: Field injection is preferred over constructor injection from a unit testing standpoint.
choices.A: If there is only one constructor the @Autowired annotation is not required.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true concerning constructor injection? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A: @Autowired is not necessary if you have one constructor that instantiates the fields
C: Constructor injection is preferred over field injection, as it helps with unit testing. Most IDE's will warn you against field injection anyways.
Field injection is ambiguous and doesn't really tell you which dependencies are mandatory.

Selected Answer: AC
See other comments why

Selected Answer: AC
Contructor injection is preferred because it allows for easier unit testing. If only one constructor is available it will be used to inject dependencies without the need of @Autowired annotation.

As of Spring Framework 4.3, an @Autowired annotation on such a constructor is no longer necessary if the target bean only defines one constructor to begin with.
Answer A and C

choices.D: The logging levels of a package that can be accessed via the loggers endpoint include configuredLevel and effectiveLevel.
choices.C: In order to use the loggers endpoint, a logger implementation dependency needs to be added.
choices.B: An application restart is required to change the logging level of the package.
choices.A: To get a logging level of a package called account.web, you can access the /actuator/loggers/account.web endpoint.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
for a package account.web the way to get or update the logging level is by the endpoint /actuator/loggers/account.web.

@james2033
You created the Question with A & Das correct answers. But in the comment section you are voting for B & D???

Selected Answer: BD
In application.properties , add
logging.level.root=INFO
management.endpoints.web.exposure.include=*

Go to endpoint http://localhost:8080/actuator/loggers

See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77969003/why-spring-boot-actuator-logger-end-point-did-not-work
